literature_search.ai_response:
I'll search the literature database for recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus (past few years). I'll return key details and links.## Recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus — curated list

Below are recent, relevant research articles (2021–2025) returned from the literature search. For each paper I list the citation, journal, publication date, a 1–2 sentence summary focused on synaptic plasticity, and the article link. When the tool returned an image URL I embedded it (alt-text provided). If you want the full text for any open/public article I can attempt to fetch it with the read-paper tool.

### 1) Bidirectional synaptic plasticity rapidly modifies hippocampal representations  
- **Authors:** Aaron D. Milstein et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** eLife (2021)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.73046 — [Full text (open access) via eLife article page](https://elifesciences.org/articles/73046)  
- **Short summary:** Demonstrates how bidirectional forms of synaptic plasticity can quickly reshape hippocampal place-cell representations; provides physiological evidence linking rapid synaptic changes to representation updates during learning.  
- **Image:** ![eLife icon](https://elifesciences.org/assets/images/social/icon-600x600@1.52e87ee6.png)

---

### 2) Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus  
- **Authors:** Antoine D. Madar, Anqi Jiang, Can Dong, Mark E. J. Sheffield, et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature Neuroscience (2025-03-20)  
- **Link:** [Nature Neuroscience article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01894-6)  
- **Short summary:** Combines computational models and in vivo data to compare candidate plasticity rules; finds behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) better explains trial-by-trial place-field shifting than classical STDP and highlights differences between CA1 and CA3 plasticity dynamics.  
- **Image:** ![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01894-6/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1894_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons  
- **Authors:** Kevin C. Gonzalez, Adrian Negrean, Zhenrui Liao, Satoshi Terada, Guofeng Zhang, et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature (2024-12-18 / article metadata shows 2025)  
- **Link:** [Nature article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9)  
- **Short summary:** Uses an all-optical approach to monitor synaptic events and plasticity at single-neuron resolution in behaving animals, linking local synaptic changes to the emergence of feature/selective responses in hippocampal neurons (place-field related).  
- **Image:** ![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus  
- **Authors:** Sachin P. Vaidya, Guanchun Li, Raymond A. Chitwood, Yiding Li, Jeffrey C. Magee, et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature Neuroscience (2025-06-04)  
- **Link:** [Nature Neuroscience article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
- **Short summary:** Tracks CA1 place cells across multiple days of learning and links increases in stability and retrieval to repeated rounds of behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP), proposing a cascade model where each active day increases neuron-specific plasticity likelihood.  
- **Image:** ![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 5) Systems consolidation reorganizes hippocampal engram circuitry  
- **Authors:** Sangyoon Y. Ko, Yiming Rong, Adam I. Ramsaran, Xiaoyu Chen, Asim J. Rashid, Andrew J. Mocle, Sheena A. Josselyn, Paul W. Frankland, et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature (2025-05-14)  
- **Link:** [Nature article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08993-1)  
- **Short summary:** Shows time-dependent rewiring of hippocampal engram circuitry during systems consolidation; implicates reorganization of synaptic connections (and thus plasticity-mediated circuit changes) as a mechanism for shifts in memory precision and generalization.  
- **Image:** ![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-025-08993-1/MediaObjects/41586_2025_8993_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 6) Entorhinal cortex directs learning-related changes in CA1 representations  
- **Authors:** (Magee lab) Jeffrey C. Magee et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature (2022-11-02)  
- **Link:** [Nature article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05378-6)  
- **Short summary:** Provides physiological and optogenetic evidence that entorhinal cortex layer 3 (EC3) input drives dendritic events and BTSP in CA1, explaining how instructive inputs can direct synaptic plasticity to shape hippocampal representations during learning.  
- **Image:** ![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-022-05378-6/MediaObjects/41586_2022_5378_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

## Notes and next steps
- These results include a mix of experimental, computational, and conceptual studies emphasizing behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP), place-field dynamics, and circuit reorganization during memory formation and consolidation.

web_search.user: Search the web for information about NEURON simulation software.
web_search.ai_response:
I'll search the web now for information about NEURON simulation software.I'll summarize the web search results for the NEURON simulation software and provide key links and pointers to documentation, tutorials, installation, and resources.

## Overview
- **NEURON** — a widely used simulation environment for modeling individual neurons and networks of neurons. It is designed for models with complex morphology and biophysics and supports single-cell to network simulations, running on local machines, clusters, and cloud services.
- Key features:
  - Flexible representation of branched cable sections and spatially varying properties
  - User-extendable biophysical mechanisms (NMODL / ChannelBuilder)
  - Interfaces: **Python**, **HOC**, and a graphical user interface (GUI)
  - Support for parallel/HPC simulations (MPI)
  - Open source, actively maintained and documented

![NEURON overview screenshot](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/_images/neuron-overview.jpg)

## Official documentation and getting started
- **NEURON documentation (main)** — comprehensive docs and entry point for guides, programmer’s reference, examples, installation instructions, recorded classes and links to ModelDB.  
  (Link: [The NEURON Simulator — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/))

- **How to get started with NEURON** — step-by-step start guide covering installation, basic usage, GUI tips, NMODL guidance, and recommended resources (forum, ModelDB, tutorials).  
  (Link: [How to get started with NEURON — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html))

- **Guides and tutorials (Yale / NEURON site)** — programmer’s reference, beginner tutorials, GUI tool walkthroughs (CellBuilder, ChannelBuilder, Import3D), Python scripting examples, optimization tools, reaction-diffusion and more. Good for structured learning.  
  (Link: [Guides and tutorials | NEURON](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs))

## Installation
- Recommended installs:
  - Python/Pip: pip install neuron (works on Linux and macOS; also on cloud notebooks via !pip)
  - Windows: use the official Windows installer from the NEURON site
  - For parallel simulations, install an MPI implementation and the MPI-enabled NEURON build
- Building from source and troubleshooting instructions available in the docs.

## Extending NEURON: NMODL and ChannelBuilder
- **NMODL**: NEURON’s mechanism definition language used to write ion channels, pumps, etc. Note: as of NEURON >= 9.0, NMODL is translated into C++ (compatibility notes in docs).
- **ChannelBuilder**: GUI-based alternative to NMODL for specifying channels; recommended when possible because it’s easier and can be faster than hand-written NMODL.
- The docs include guidance on adapting older MOD files for newer NEURON versions.

## Model repositories and examples
- **ModelDB** — repository of published NEURON models and example code. A primary resource to find runnable models and learn patterns used in published work. NEURON docs point to ModelDB examples as practical starting points.

## Learning resources
- Recorded NEURON classes and course materials linked from the docs.
- Tutorials included in documentation (basic and advanced topics), exercises from NEURON courses, and GUI tool demos.
- NEURON Forum — community support and Q&A.

## Additional notes from search results
- NEURON emphasizes separating biological model specification from numerical implementation (cable sections, continuous properties).
- It includes tools for optimization (Multiple Run Fitter), network building, data-heavy simulation strategies, and reaction-diffusion modeling.
- NEURON is commonly used in both experimental and theoretical neuroscience research.

## Found pages (search hits)
- The NEURON documentation main site — “The NEURON Simulator” (nrn.readthedocs.io)
- “How to get started with NEURON” guide (nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html)
- NEURON guides & tutorials (neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs)
- Legacy/versioned guides (nrn.readthedocs.io/en/8.2.6/guide/)
- An overview PDF/course handout summarizing NEURON (maths.nottingham.ac.uk…/CNN5.pdf)

If you want, I can:
- Walk through installing NEURON on your platform (Linux/macOS/Windows) and show exact commands.
- Find specific tutorials (e.g., Python scripting examples, ChannelBuilder, NMODL examples).
- Search ModelDB for models of a particular cell type or brain region.

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology
```

I'll fetch the latest entitysdk documentation and examples on listing cell morphologies in Python. I'll use the OBI docs tool now.## Listing all cell morphologies with the EntitySDK (Python)

Below is a concise, ready-to-run example that shows how to:
- initialize the EntitySDK client (authentication),
- list / paginate through **CellMorphology** entities,
- filter by species and brain region,
- inspect assets and download an SWC file,
- and handle entity links/metadata.

All code uses the patterns and examples from the EntitySDK documentation.

### Prerequisites
- Install and import the EntitySDK package used in the examples (project uses `entitysdk`).
- Set an access token in the environment (here we read `ACCESS_TOKEN`), and have your `project_context` (virtual lab id + project id) ready.

---

### Example: list, filter, paginate, and download assets

```python
import os
from pathlib import Path

from entitysdk.client import Client
from entitysdk.common import ProjectContext
from entitysdk.models import CellMorphology, Species

# ---- Configuration (update these to match your project) ----
ENTITYCORE_API_URL = \http://127.0.0.1:8000\   # or the environment/staging URL you use
PROJECT_CONTEXT = ProjectContext(
    virtual_lab_id=\a98b7abc-fc46-4700-9e3d-37137812c730",
    project_id=\0dbced5f-cc3d-488a-8c7f-cfb8ea039dc6",
)
TOKEN = os.getenv(\ACCESS_TOKEN", \REPLACE_WITH_TOKEN")

# ---- Initialize client ----
client = Client(api_url=ENTITYCORE_API_URL, project_context=PROJECT_CONTEXT, token_manager=TOKEN)

# ---- Search / iterate through CellMorphology entities (no filter: get all) ----
# Option 1: iterator with no limit (streams all results page-by-page)
all_morphologies_iter = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={},   # empty query -> no filters
    limit=None, # None means no limit (retrieve everything via the iterator)
)

print(\Listing cell morphologies (streaming iterator):")
for morphology in all_morphologies_iter:
    print(f"- ID: {morphology.id}  Name: {morphology.name}")

# ---- Search with pagination explicitly (page / page_size) ----
page = 1
page_size = 10
query = {\page": page, \page_size": page_size}

paged_hits = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query=query, limit=None).all()
print(f"\nPage {page} ({len(paged_hits)} results):")
for m in paged_hits:
    print(f\  ID: {m.id}  Name: {m.name}")

# ---- Filter by species and brain region (example) ----
# The query keys follow the API model fields.
# Example: filter by species label (scientific name) and by brain region label
query = {
    \subject__species__label": \Mus musculus",              # species filter (scientific name)
     rain_region__label": \Primary motor cortex",         # brain region filter
    \page": 1,
    \page_size": 20,
}

filtered_iter = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query=query, limit=100)
print("\nFiltered results (species + brain region):")
for morph in filtered_iter:
    print(f\ - {morph.id} : {morph.name}  (species: {getattr(morph.subject, 'species', None)})")

# ---- Alternative filter using mtype (mtype__pref_label) ----
mtype_query = {\mtype__pref_label": \L5_TPC:A"}
mtype_iter = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query=mtype_query, limit=50)
print("\nFiltered by mtype (L5_TPC:A):")
for m in mtype_iter:
    print(f\ - {m.id} : {m.name}")

# ---- Fetch a single morphology in detail and handle its assets (download SWC) ----
# Replace this ID with one returned above
example_id = "<replace-with-morphology-id>"

if example_id and example_id != "<replace-with-morphology-id>":
    fetched = client.get_entity(entity_id=example_id, entity_type=CellMorphology)

    print(f"\nFetched morphology: {fetched.id} - {fetched.name}")
    print(\Description:", fetched.description)
    print(\Assets:")
    for asset in fetched.assets:
        print(f\  - Asset ID: {asset.id}  content_type: {asset.content_type}  filename: {asset.filename}")

    # Download assets with content type \application/swc\ to a local path
    downloaded = client.download_assets(
        fetched,
        selection={\content_type": \application/swc"},
        output_path="./downloaded-morphology.swc",
    ).one()  # .one() if we expect a single match

    # Optionally read asset content (small binary/text)
    content = client.download_content(entity_id=fetched.id, entity_type=type(fetched), asset_id=downloaded.asset.id)
    print("\nSWC content preview (first 300 chars):")
    print(content[:300])

else:
    print("\nNo example morphology ID provided. Use one of the IDs listed above to fetch and download assets.")
```

---

## Notes, tips, and patterns (from the docs)
- Initialization: create `Client(api_url, project_context, token_manager)` — token commonly from environment (`ACCESS_TOKEN`) or from an auth helper for staging.
- Listing:
  - `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={}, limit=None)` returns an iterator streaming all results page-by-page.
  - Use `query` to pass paging arguments `\page"` and `\page_size"` for manual pagination.
- Filtering:
  - Use nested keys like `\subject__species__label\`, `\mtype__pref_label\`, or ` rain_location__brain_region__label\`.
- Assets:
  - Use `client.download_assets(fetched, selection={...}, output_path=\...").one()` to download selected assets (e.g., SWC).
  - Use `client.download_content(entity_id, entity_type, asset_id)` to get asset content programmatically.
- Deleting assets: iterate `fetched.assets`, identify by `asset.content_type`, then `client.delete_asset(...)`, then re-fetch entity to confirm.

pricing_simulation_costs.expected_output:
## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

I'll design a CIRCUIT simulation configuration for that circuit now (100 neurons, 500 ms, current clamp at 50 ms). I'll call the simulation design tool.## Clarification needed before I generate the config

I tried to create the CIRCUIT simulation config but the platform requires a valid UUID for the `circuit_id`. You supplied **abc123**, which is not a UUID.

Please choose one of the options below so I can proceed:

1. **Provide the circuit UUID** (preferred) — paste the full UUID for circuit **abc123** and I will generate the simulation config for that circuit.
2. **Let me omit the circuit_id** — I will design a generic CIRCUIT simulation config (as you requested: 100 neurons, 500 ms, IClamp at 50 ms) without tying it to a specific circuit UUID. The frontend/app state can later infer or attach the correct circuit ID.
3. **Tell me to stop** — if you want to change parameters before I generate the config.

Summary of the requested simulation I'll produce once you confirm:
- **Number of neurons:** 100  
- **Simulation duration:** 500 ms  
- **Stimulus:** single current clamp (*IClamp*) starting at **50 ms**, duration **100 ms**, amplitude **0.5 nA**, applied to a neuron_set named **stim_target** (by default 1 randomly chosen neuron; can be changed)  
- **Recordings:** soma membrane voltage (V_m) from neurons in **stim_target** and spike times for the whole network  
- **Description:** \100-neuron test, 500 ms, single current clamp at 50 ms."

Which option would you like? If you choose (2) or (1) with a valid UUID, I'll generate the simulation config now.

arguments.config_request: Create a new CIRCUIT simulation for circuit abc123 with the following settings: - Initialize the circuit with 100 neurons (number_neurons: 100). - Simulation length: 500 ms. - Initialization: set v_init to default (no special value), random_seed left unspecified. - Stimulus: add a current clamp (IClamp) applied to a representative set of neurons (e.g., a neuron_set named 'stim_target' containing 1 neuron selected randomly unless more are required). The current clamp should start at t = 50 ms, duration 100 ms, amplitude 0.5 nA (adjustable). - Recordings: record soma membrane voltage (V_m) from all neurons in the 'stim_target' neuron_set and spike times for the whole network. - Provide a short description: '100-neuron test, 500 ms, single current clamp at 50 ms.' - Do not include other manipulations. - Return a simulation config suitable for running as a CIRCUIT simulation. Please produce only the configuration request (do not include full JSON in chat).

I found morphologies within the **Cerebellum** (Brain region **ID: 062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf**). Total items in this region: **66**. Below are the first 5 morphologies returned (page 1, page_size 5).

---

### 1) **soma_10c** — **ID: e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9**
- **Description:** Soma as a flask-like shape with a radius around 7.5 µm; located in the Purkinje cell layer. Dendrites are flat, large and highly branched (dendritic tree) in the molecular layer. Single long axon descending to the white matter — the principal output of the cerebellum.
- **Mtype:** **CBXpu_PuC** (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell)
- **Created by:** Aurelien Jaquier; Contributors include Hermina Nedelescu and Tokyo Medical and Dental University
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

### 2) **01bc** — **ID: d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70**
- **Description:** Soma pyramidal/oval (~6 µm radius) in inner 1/3 of molecular layer. Dendrites long and straight extending toward pia with few branches. Axon runs parallel to Purkinje cell layer with descending and ascending collaterals.
- **Mtype:** **CBXmo_BC** (Cerebellum Basket Cell)
- **Created by:** Aurelien Jaquier; Contributor: Diana Sánchez-Ponce; organization: Technical University of Madrid
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

### 3) **stellate** — **ID: 00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53**
- **Description:** Small fusiform soma (~4 µm radius) in outer 2/3 of molecular layer. Dendrites long, thin, contorted, aspinous, branching in all directions. Axon branches immediately into short collaterals.
- **Mtype:** **CBXmo_StC** (Cerebellum Stellate Cell)

### 4) **pair-140514-C2-1_split_1** — **ID: cb635d11-f5f4-4ec5-8c6e-3e5af6d4eb6c**
- **Description:** Soma round/polygonal (~8 µm radius) in granular layer. 4–10 dendrites split into basal (remain in granular layer, contorted) and apical (ascend into molecular layer forming a fan-shaped tree). Axons thin beaded fibers forming a large axon plexus in granular layer.

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
I'll search recent literature for neuron morphology studies focused on the cerebrum. I'll retrieve several recent papers (past ~5 years).## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — selected papers (2020–2026)

Below are recent, high-impact papers and preprints focused on neuronal morphology, dendrite/axon structure, and whole‑brain or cortical single‑neuron reconstructions covering cerebral cortex / cerebrum-related areas. For each entry I include the citation, a short summary (from the search results), a direct link, and the article image when available.

---

### 1) **An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex** (2025)
- **Journal:** Nature Communications (2025-04-09)  
- **Summary:** Unsupervised mapping of excitatory neuron dendritic morphologies in mouse visual cortex; builds a morphological taxonomy of dendritic shapes using large-scale reconstructions.  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
- Image:  
  ![Dendritic morphology figure from Nature Communications 2025](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) **Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry** (2024)
- **Journal:** Nature Communications (2024-11-26)  
- **Summary:** Whole‑brain morphometry revealing neuronal diversity and stereotyped morphologies across scales; provides a large-scale morphometric atlas (whole‑brain emphasis, relevant to cerebral neuron diversity).  
- **Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=9de490d8-2096-42e3-a5d6-bcf63bd6ac17)  
- Image:  
  ![Whole-brain morphometry figure from Nature Communications 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) **Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker‑related somatosensory cortices** (2024) — preprint / reviewed
- **Server/Preprint:** eLife reviewed preprint (versions 2024, open)  
- **Summary:** Cell class–specific, layer- and sublayer-resolved description of long‑range axonal projections from genetically-defined excitatory neuron classes in somatosensory cortex; includes brain‑wide light-sheet imaging and functional optogenetic validation. Relevant for cerebral cortical projection neuron morphology and axonal outputs.  
- **Link:** [Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections … (eLife)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602)  
- Image:  
  ![eLife logo and article artwork](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/_next/static/media/elife-logo.2ab2ee88.svg)

---

### 4) **Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro‑ and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy** (2024; reviewed preprint v2 Nov 2024)
- **Server/Preprint:** eLife reviewed preprint (v2 Nov 26, 2024; Part I: Anatomy)  
- **Summary:** Comprehensive anatomical description supporting modeling of neocortical micro‑ and mesocircuitry; extensive morphological datasets and constraints for circuit reconstructions in cortex. (Large collaborative effort e.g., Blue Brain / Markram et al.)  
- **Link:** [Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro‑ and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v2)  
- Image:  
  ![eLife logo and article artwork](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/_next/static/media/elife-logo.2ab2ee88.svg)

---

### 5) **Morphological diversity of single neurons in molecularly defined cell types** (2021)
- **Journal:** Nature (2021-10-06)  
- **Summary:** Large study linking molecular cell types to morphological diversity at single‑neuron resolution; details morphological variation within molecularly-defined cortical cell classes. Important background and reference for morphology ↔ transcriptomic cell‑type relationships in cerebral cortex.  
- **Link / DOI:** [Morphological diversity of single neurons in molecularly defined cell types](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-021-03941-1?error=cookies_not_supported&code=dfa0ed05-2358-49ef-8acc-07acddbabb61)  
- Image:  
  ![Figure from Nature 2021 showing morphological diversity](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-021-03941-1/MediaObjects/41586_2021_3941_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 6) **Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex** (2023)
- **Journal:** Nature Neuroscience (2023-05-22)  
- **Summary:** Nearly 2,000 complete dendrite and axon reconstructions in mouse prefrontal cortex; classification of dendritic subtypes, relations between dendritic and axonal morphology, and implications for intra‑ and inter‑area connectivity. Directly relevant to cerebral cortex neuron morphology and network organization.  
- **Link:** [Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons … (Nature Neuroscience)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y)  
- Image:  
  ![Figure from Nature Neuroscience 2023 illustrating reconstructions](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 7) **Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain** (2024)
- **Journal:** Nature (2024-10-02)  
- **Summary:** Large-scale wiring diagram (connectomic) with morphological reconstructions linking cellular morphology to wiring in an adult brain. While not limited solely to cerebrum, this study provides detailed morphology + connectivity maps that are highly relevant to understanding cerebral neuron morphologies in a wiring context.  
- **Link:** [Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07558-y)  
- Image:  
  ![Figure from Nature 2024 — neuronal wiring diagram](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07558-y/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7558_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

## Would you like:
- Full-text retrieval of any of these (I can attempt to read full articles using the read-paper tool if you want a deeper summary)?  
- A focused subset (e.g., only visual cortex, prefrontal cortex, or only studies with single‑neuron reconstructions)?  
- Links to the underlying morphology datasets (where available) or help locating reconstructions you can download?

Note: I can fetch full text for any publicly available paper using the read‑paper tool—tell me which one(s) you'd like me to retrieve.

I'll search the platform glossary for the definition of \ME-model".## Definition

**ME-model** (morphoelectric model)

**Definition:** *An ME-model, or morphoelectric model*, is a combination of an **E-model** (electrical model) with the relevant neuronal **morphology**. ME-models can be simulated using [BlueCelluLab](https://github.com/openbraininstitute/BlueCelluLab) and serve as essential elements in circuit building.

## Notes
- **Purpose:** Integrates a neuron's morphology (shape, dendrites, axon, soma) with its electrical properties for realistic single-cell simulations.
- **Usage on the platform:** ME-models are used as building blocks for circuits and can be executed with platform-supported simulation tools (e.g., BlueCelluLab).

(Source: platform glossary — \ME-model")

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?

I'll fetch the latest documentation for the obi-one package and find a single-cell simulation example.## Single-cell simulation example using **obi-one**

Below is a complete, self-contained Python example that shows the typical workflow for creating, validating and running a single-cell (MEModel) simulation with *obi-one*. It follows the patterns shown in the official examples returned from the OBI-One docs.

- Steps shown:
  1. Build an MEModel simulation configuration (timestamps, stimulus, recordings, initialization)
  2. Validate the configuration
  3. Create a grid scan task (if scanning multiple stimulus amplitudes)
  4. Execute the simulation via the provided runner

Note: adapt IDs, file paths, and parameters to your environment (MEModel/circuit IDs, output directory, simulator choice).

```python
# single_cell_memodel_simulation.py
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Simulation parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms
output_root = Path("./obi_output/memodel_single_cell")

# === 1) Build an empty MEModelSimulationScanConfig ===
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info (metadata)
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Single-Cell Simulation",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with current clamp"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# Regular timestamps (use to reference repeated stimuli or trials)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(
    start_time=0.0,
    number_of_repetitions=1,
    interval=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=\RegularTimestamps")

# Stimulus: somatic constant current clamp
# amplitude can be a single float (single run) or a list [0.1, 0.2] to create a scan
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,    # ms
    amplitude=0.5       # nA  (or [0.2, 0.5, 0.8] for a scan)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput")

# Recordings: soma voltage (you can set time windows or full trace)
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name=\VoltageRecording")

time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(
    start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0
)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name=\TimeWindowVoltageRecording")

# === Initialization block ===
# Replace `memodel_id_str` with the ID of the MEModel entity you want to simulate.
memodel_id_str = \PUT_MEMODEL_ID_HERE"

simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=memodel_id_str),
    simulation_length=sim_duration,
    # optional: v_init=-80.0, random_seed=42, etc.
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name=\initialize")

# === Validate the configuration ===
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated simulation config:")
print(validated_sim_conf)

# === 2) If you used multiple amplitude values (a scan), create and execute a GridScanGenerationTask ===
# For a single-value amplitude, you can skip the grid-scan and run the validated config directly with run().

# Example: create grid-scan task (only necessary if you have scan parameters)
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX",
    output_root=str(output_root / \grid_scan")
)

# Optional: inspect multiple-value parameters and coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute the generation (this writes scan coordinates / simulation configs)
# Note: execution may require a configured OBI client / DB client in your environment.
# If your environment requires a db_client, provide it. Otherwise, certain helper runners may accept only the config path.
# grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)

# === 3) Run simulation(s) using the high-level runner ===
# For simple cases you can use obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution.run
# This function accepts a simulation_config path or validated config; adapt as needed.

# If you have a `simulation_config` file path:
# simulation_config_path = "/path/to/validated_sim_conf.json"
# obi.run(simulation_config=simulation_config_path, simulator= luecellulab", save_nwb=False)

# If you generated a grid scan and want to run all generated tasks:
# obi.run_tasks_for_generated_scan(grid_scan, db_client=db_client)

# For a minimal single run using the validated form, an example call is:
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# If the `run` helper accepts the validated config object directly, pass it; otherwise save to a config file and pass the path.
# Here we show the file-path variant—save the validated config first (pseudo-code; adapt to the object's API)
validated_config_path = output_root / \validated_sim_conf.json"
validated_config_path.parent.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
with open(validated_config_path, \w") as fh:
    fh.write(validated_sim_conf.json())  # .json(): adapt based on actual API of validated_sim_conf

# Execute with BlueCelluLab (or 
eurodamus")
run(
    simulation_config=str(validated_config_path),
    simulator= luecellulab",
    save_nwb=False
)

print(\Simulation submitted. Check output directory:", output_root)
```

### Notes and pointers
- Replace **memodel_id_str** with the actual MEModel entity ID you want to simulate.
- If you want multiple runs over parameter values (e.g., several stimulus amplitudes), set `amplitude=[0.2,0.5,0.8]` when creating the stimulus; the config will become a grid-scan and you can use `GridScanGenerationTask` + `obi.run_tasks_for_generated_scan(...)`.
- The example shows the high-level runner:
  - obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution.run(simulation_config=..., simulator= luecellulab")
  - Or use `obi.run_tasks_for_generated_scan()` for generated grid scans.
- The exact methods to serialize `validated_sim_conf` or how `run()` expects the configuration (object vs. file path) may depend on your installed version of *obi-one*; adapt the save/serialization to your environment. The code snippets above are taken directly from the official examples in the OBI-One repository and should be adapted as needed.
